task.title: Creating concept topics
task.shortdesc: Provide concept topics that give background for tasks, and that describe the underlying model behind a product's design.

taskbody.prereq: Before you starting writing concepts, you should have a concept hierarchy derived from an analysis of user scenarios and tasks, as well as from product design documents.
taskbody.context: Concepts should not be just a list of features for a product: they should help users determine how their use model maps to the product's design model, and provide the background material they require to perform tasks.

step.cmd: Provide a title for the concept.
step.info: Concept titles should be a noun or noun phrase, and use generic terms that will make sense to new users, rather than using product-specific terminology.

step.cmd: Provide an ID for the concept.
step.info: The ID must start with a letter and contain only letters and numbers.

step.cmd: Save the file and give it a name.
step.stepxmp: Concepts are often stored in a \concepts subdirectory. Some conventions suggest starting the file name with a "c" for concept, to ensure that you don't end up with a concept and task with the same filename in separate directories.

step.cmd: Provide a short description for the concept.
step.info: This could provide a brief definition of the subject. Consider putting the definition in a <ph> element, so that it can be reused in a glossary.
You can use sections when necessary, but make sure you are not using sections to document what should be additional concepts. Drawings or diagrams are often helpful in concepts.

step.cmd: Save the concept, and make sure that any map references to it use the appropriate path and file name.

taskbody.result: You now have a concept that can be included in maps and built into help sets, Web sites, and PDFs.
